snippet: Some officials credited a warning system for the relatively small number of injuries and deaths from unrelenting storms over the weekend in the Midwest.
abstract: Relatively few people are killed or injured during the 24 hours in which more than 100 tornadoes descended upon the Midwest; some officials have attributed the relatively few casualties to a more vigilant and persistent warning system than in the past.

byline.original: By MANNY FERNANDEZ and MATT FLEGENHEIMER
byline.contributor: Manny Fernandez reported from Woodward, and Matt Flegenheimer from New York. Channing Joseph contributed reporting from New York.

lead_paragraph: Some officials credited a warning system for the relatively small number of injuries and deaths from unrelenting storms over the weekend in the Midwest.

headline.seo: 100 Tornadoes in 24 Hours, but Plenty of Notice
headline.main: 100 Tornadoes in 24 Hours, but Plenty of Notice
headline.print_headline: 100 Tornadoes in 24 Hours, but Plenty of Notice
